BILL LORING receives a check from PRESIDENT LOWELL J.
REED to kick off the WUS drive.
The World University Service
Drive starts April 8 and ends April
14, with the Ugly Man contest
running throughout the week,
Chairman Lew Sank announced
this week.
Bill Loring, chairman of the
drive, disclosed the schedule for
the week. Several Booster Club
members will be shining shoes at
Levering Hall during the rush
hours. Members of the faculty will
serve as waiters at one meal at
Levering Hall, and several Goucher girls will serve as waitresses at
a special dormitory dinner.
Plans are also being made for a
variety show to be held April 11.
Mr.,Bridgers of the Physical Education Department will serve as
auctioneer at the Levering Great
Hall auction at 10 a.m. on April
13. Baked goods and unclaimed
articles from the lost and found
department will be among the articles auctioned.
Prior to the drive, there will be
a Student Council assembly at

which more information concerning the project will be available.
The candidates for the Ugly Man
contest will be introduced at a "Y"
mixer the evening of the assembly.
World University Service is an
international organization which
seeks to assist needy students and
schools throughout the world. This
year, the Hopkins group has undertaken to contribute $800, an
average of approximately $.50 for
each undergraduate student.
President Lowell J. Reed stated
his approval of the drive in a
letter sent to the World University Service leaders on campus.

service fraternity, from 9 a.m. to

tonight between 5:15 and 6:15
p.m.

charged, according to Rierson, to
insure "against a whole lot of
guys signing up for the car wash
and then not showing up." The
cost of washing a car will be 75c
inside vacuuming, 25c, and white
side-wall cleaning, 25c.

maybe about seven to nine cars

minutes to a car and that is pushing them through pretty fast,"

maximum number of cars that we
can handle is, but if we still have
cars left to do at 3 p.m., some of
the guys will work overtime to
finish them."
Rierson revealed that the proceeds will be used to strengthen
the fund for next year's projects
and that all members of the fraternity will be working on the
Car Wash project. The other
members of the Car Wash Committee are Al Stone and Alan

A Constructive Suggestion
The Student Council, as a body whose basic difficulty
over the years has been a chronic inability to define its own
role, stands or fails on the abilities of its president. It is he
who sets--,-or forces—the pace; his position of leadership
in an undefined sphere makes it vital that he be a man who
has original ideas and the persuasiveness to swing the rest
of the Council behind him.
Yet the voter here has no opportunity of seeing the
candidates in a crossfire such as the man eventually elected
has to face. The thinking man, whose mind is not already made
up, has no way to estimate the capacities of the presidential
hopefuls, except by reading the campaign blurbs in this paper,
, which are often written, if not in pleasant generalities, by
astute ghosts behind the scenes.
To remedy this lack, we strongly urge the SC to consider this plan: set up a panel discussion, with the floor
thrown open to questions, among the candidates. Remsen 1
would be a good site; Debate Council chief Herb Butler
would be an able moderator. We ourselves, for a start, have

BILL LORING receives a check from PRESIDENT LOWELL J.

The World University Service
Drive starts April 8 and ends April
14, with the Ugly Man contest
running throughout the week,
Chairman Lew Sank announced
this week.
Bill Loring, chairman of the
drive, disclosed the schedule for
the week. Several Booster Club
members will be shining shoes at
Levering Hall during the rush
hours. Members of the faculty will
serve as waiters at one meal at
Levering Hall, and several Goucher girls will serve as waitresses at
a special dormitory dinner.
Plans are also being made for a
variety show to be held April 11.
Mr.,Bridgers of the Physical Education Department will serve as
auctioneer at the Levering Great
Hall auction at 10 a.m. on April
13. Baked goods and unclaimed
articles from the lost and found
department will be among the articles auctioned.
Prior to the drive, there will be
a Student Council assembly at

which more information concerning the project will be available.
The candidates for the Ugly Man
contest will be introduced at a "Y"
mixer the evening of the assembly.
World University Service is an
international organization which
seeks to assist needy students and
schools throughout the world. This
year, the Hopkins group has undertaken to contribute $800, an
average of approximately $.50 for
each undergraduate student.
President Lowell J. Reed stated
his approval of the drive in a
letter sent to the World University Service leaders on campus.
